title: WCAS PHIL 390-0-21 Special Topics In Philosophy

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the philosophical contributions of Ludwig Wittgenstein, one of the most polarizing philosophers of the 20th century. We'll examine his views of logic, language, and their limits in his early period. We'll then examine his treatment of mental content, mathematics, and the publicity of languages in his middle period, with an eye toward the transition to his later period. In examining his later works we'll emphasize his meta-philosophical outlook and the continuity of his thought and methods.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: One prior course in philosophy recommended.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To write clearly and effectively on Wittgenstein and other philosophical topics. 2) To read methodically Wittgenstein's unorthodox texts, in light of their context. 3) To engage Wittgenstein's thought while avoiding the dangers of dismissiveness and hero-worship.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Required Texts: Wittgenstein, Major Works, Harper Perennial Modern Classics. ISBN: 978-0061550249 Wittgenstein, Philosophical Investigations, 4th Edition, Wiley Blackwell. ISBN: 978-1405159289
